paper_title: Photocatalytic reduction of carbon dioxide on NiO/InTaO4 under visible light irradiation

catalyst.source: The semiconductor catalysts, such as InTaO 4 , have been extensively used for water splitting under visible light irradiation.
catalyst.context: Developing a photocatalyst system for the conversion of solar energy to electric energy or chemical energy is a topic of great interest with fundamental and practical importance.The semiconductor catalysts, such as InTaO 4 , have been extensively used for water splitting under visible light irradiation.However, it has not been used for photoreduction of carbon dioxide with water.InTaO 4 was synthesized by solid-state reaction.NiO was added by incipient-wetness impregnation method as the cocatalysts.The catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy (UV-Vis) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS).The photocatalytic reduction was carried out in a Pyrex reactor under visible light illumination using 500 W halogen light as the light source.The band gap of InTaO 4 was estimated, from UV-Vis spectrum, to be 2.6 eV, showing that these catalysts have ability to reduce CO 2 into methanol.The effects of the NiO cocatalyst and pretreatment process on the photocatalytic reduction of the catalyst to methanol were investigated.The methanol yield increased with the amount of NiO cocatalyst.The reduction-oxidation pretreatment had a positive effect on the catalyst.

catalyst.source: The Ni-loaded photocatalysts were calcined at 350 C for 1 h in air (denoted as NiO-InTaO 4 ).
catalyst.context: The polycrystalline InTaO 4 was synthesized by solidstate reaction with In 2 O 3 and Ta 2 O 5 as the starting materials.The stoichiometric amounts of precursors were mixed and reacted in an alumina crucible in air at 1100 C for 12 h.In order to obtain high photocatalytic activity, it is needed to load a metal or metal oxide on the surface of photocatalyst as electron acceptors.NiO cocatalyst was loaded by incipient-wetness impregnation with aqueous solution of Ni(NO 3 ) 2 .The Ni-loaded photocatalysts were calcined at 350 C for 1 h in air (denoted as NiO-InTaO 4 ).It was then pretreated by H 2 reduction at 500 C for 2 h and subsequent O 2 oxidation at 200 C for 1 h (denoted as NiO-InTaO 4 R500-O200).The core-shell structure of metallic Ni and NiO was formed on the surface of the catalyst by this reduction-oxidation procedure. The XRD experiments were preformed using a Siemens D-500 powder diffractometer with Cu Ka radiation (40 kV, 41 mA), 0.024step size and 1 s step time from 5to 90.The Bragg-Brentano focusing geometry was employed with an automatic divergence slit (irradiated sample length was 12.5 nm), a receiving slit of 0.1 nm, a fixed slit of 4a nd a proportional counter as a detector. Scanning electron microscopy images were obtained with a Hitachi S-800 field emission microscope using an acceleration voltage of 20 kV.Samples were placed on a stage especially made for SEM.Samples were coated with Au prior to analysis and imaged directly.SEM images were recorded at magnification of 5000 and 10000.The magnification was calibrated in pixel/nm on the camera.The chemical composition of the samples was determined by X-ray energy dispersion spectrum (EDS) with accelerating voltage of 20 kV. The diffuse reflectance UV-Vis was measured with a Cary 300 Bio UV-visible spectrophotometer.Powder samples were loaded in a quartz cell with Suprasil windows, and spectra were collected in the range from 300 to 800 nm against quartz standard. Photocatalytic reactions were carried out in a continuous flow reactor.The catalyst powder (0.14 g) was dispersed in a reactant solution (50 ml) in a down-window type irradiation cell made of Pyrex glass (75 ml).Potassium bicarbonate (0.2 M) aqueous solutions were employed as an absorbent of carbon dioxide and the ultra pure CO 2 were added continuously into the reactor for 1 h to remove oxygen in the water, and saturated carbon dioxide in the solution.A cooling system combined with water pump was used to keep the temperature of the reactor under room temperature.Light was switched on to start the reaction, and the irradiation was continued for 20 h.The light source was a 500 W halogen lamp (Ever bright; H-500).After 20 h, the reaction solution was centrifuged for 10 min, and then 10 l of the upper stratum was drawn for analyzing the constitution.The amount of methanol was determined by a gas chromatograph (China Chromatography; GC-8900, Poropack-QS column, flame ionization detector, helium carrier gas).

catalyst.source: InTaO 4 catalyst was prepared by a solid-state reaction method.
catalyst.context: InTaO 4 catalyst was prepared by a solid-state reaction method.NiO was added as a cocatalyst by incipient-wetness impregnation, and then treated by reduction-oxidation process.The XRD patterns of InTaO 4 indicated that it is well crystallized by solid-state reaction at 1100 C.SEM results showed that the particle diameters of InTaO 4 samples were less than 3 lm.After loading NiO on the catalysts, many small particles were observed on the surface.These small particles are NiO as confirmed by EDS.The band gap of InTaO 4 was 2.7 eV.According to the energy potential of CO 2 reduction, these catalysts have ability to reduce CO 2 to methanol under visible light illumination.InTaO 4 with NiO cocatalyst after reduction-oxidation pretreatment always resulted a higher methanol yield than those without pretreatment.1.0 wt. NiO-InTaO 4 R500-O200 in 0.2 M KHCO 3 gave the highest activity (1.394 lmol h A1 g A1 ).The reduction-oxidation pretreatment had a positive effect on the activity of the catalyst, although it is not outstanding. Fig. 1.Band structure of InTaO 4 . Fig. 2. UV-Vis spectra of the catalysts, (a) InTaO 4 , (b) 1.0 wt. NiO-InTaO 4 , and (c) 1.0 wt. NiO-InTaO 4 R50-O200. P.-W.Pan, Y.-W.Chen / Catalysis Communications 8 (2007) 1546-1549 This research was supported by Industrial Technology Research Institute, Taiwan, Republic of China.

co-catalyst.source: NiO was added by incipient-wetness impregnation method as the cocatalysts.
co-catalyst.context: Developing a photocatalyst system for the conversion of solar energy to electric energy or chemical energy is a topic of great interest with fundamental and practical importance.The semiconductor catalysts, such as InTaO 4 , have been extensively used for water splitting under visible light irradiation.However, it has not been used for photoreduction of carbon dioxide with water.InTaO 4 was synthesized by solid-state reaction.NiO was added by incipient-wetness impregnation method as the cocatalysts.The catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy (UV-Vis) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS).The photocatalytic reduction was carried out in a Pyrex reactor under visible light illumination using 500 W halogen light as the light source.The band gap of InTaO 4 was estimated, from UV-Vis spectrum, to be 2.6 eV, showing that these catalysts have ability to reduce CO 2 into methanol.The effects of the NiO cocatalyst and pretreatment process on the photocatalytic reduction of the catalyst to methanol were investigated.The methanol yield increased with the amount of NiO cocatalyst.The reduction-oxidation pretreatment had a positive effect on the catalyst.

co-catalyst.source: NiO cocatalyst was loaded by incipient-wetness impregnation with aqueous solution of Ni(NO 3 ) 2 .
co-catalyst.context: The polycrystalline InTaO 4 was synthesized by solidstate reaction with In 2 O 3 and Ta 2 O 5 as the starting materials.The stoichiometric amounts of precursors were mixed and reacted in an alumina crucible in air at 1100 C for 12 h.In order to obtain high photocatalytic activity, it is needed to load a metal or metal oxide on the surface of photocatalyst as electron acceptors.NiO cocatalyst was loaded by incipient-wetness impregnation with aqueous solution of Ni(NO 3 ) 2 .The Ni-loaded photocatalysts were calcined at 350 C for 1 h in air (denoted as NiO-InTaO 4 ).It was then pretreated by H 2 reduction at 500 C for 2 h and subsequent O 2 oxidation at 200 C for 1 h (denoted as NiO-InTaO 4 R500-O200).The core-shell structure of metallic Ni and NiO was formed on the surface of the catalyst by this reduction-oxidation procedure. The XRD experiments were preformed using a Siemens D-500 powder diffractometer with Cu Ka radiation (40 kV, 41 mA), 0.024step size and 1 s step time from 5to 90.The Bragg-Brentano focusing geometry was employed with an automatic divergence slit (irradiated sample length was 12.5 nm), a receiving slit of 0.1 nm, a fixed slit of 4a nd a proportional counter as a detector. Scanning electron microscopy images were obtained with a Hitachi S-800 field emission microscope using an acceleration voltage of 20 kV.Samples were placed on a stage especially made for SEM.Samples were coated with Au prior to analysis and imaged directly.SEM images were recorded at magnification of 5000 and 10000.The magnification was calibrated in pixel/nm on the camera.The chemical composition of the samples was determined by X-ray energy dispersion spectrum (EDS) with accelerating voltage of 20 kV. The diffuse reflectance UV-Vis was measured with a Cary 300 Bio UV-visible spectrophotometer.Powder samples were loaded in a quartz cell with Suprasil windows, and spectra were collected in the range from 300 to 800 nm against quartz standard. Photocatalytic reactions were carried out in a continuous flow reactor.The catalyst powder (0.14 g) was dispersed in a reactant solution (50 ml) in a down-window type irradiation cell made of Pyrex glass (75 ml).Potassium bicarbonate (0.2 M) aqueous solutions were employed as an absorbent of carbon dioxide and the ultra pure CO 2 were added continuously into the reactor for 1 h to remove oxygen in the water, and saturated carbon dioxide in the solution.A cooling system combined with water pump was used to keep the temperature of the reactor under room temperature.Light was switched on to start the reaction, and the irradiation was continued for 20 h.The light source was a 500 W halogen lamp (Ever bright; H-500).After 20 h, the reaction solution was centrifuged for 10 min, and then 10 l of the upper stratum was drawn for analyzing the constitution.The amount of methanol was determined by a gas chromatograph (China Chromatography; GC-8900, Poropack-QS column, flame ionization detector, helium carrier gas).

co-catalyst.source: NiO was added as a cocatalyst by incipient-wetness impregnation, and then treated by reduction-oxidation process.
co-catalyst.context: InTaO 4 catalyst was prepared by a solid-state reaction method.NiO was added as a cocatalyst by incipient-wetness impregnation, and then treated by reduction-oxidation process.The XRD patterns of InTaO 4 indicated that it is well crystallized by solid-state reaction at 1100 C.SEM results showed that the particle diameters of InTaO 4 samples were less than 3 lm.After loading NiO on the catalysts, many small particles were observed on the surface.These small particles are NiO as confirmed by EDS.The band gap of InTaO 4 was 2.7 eV.According to the energy potential of CO 2 reduction, these catalysts have ability to reduce CO 2 to methanol under visible light illumination.InTaO 4 with NiO cocatalyst after reduction-oxidation pretreatment always resulted a higher methanol yield than those without pretreatment.1.0 wt. NiO-InTaO 4 R500-O200 in 0.2 M KHCO 3 gave the highest activity (1.394 lmol h A1 g A1 ).The reduction-oxidation pretreatment had a positive effect on the activity of the catalyst, although it is not outstanding. Fig. 1.Band structure of InTaO 4 . Fig. 2. UV-Vis spectra of the catalysts, (a) InTaO 4 , (b) 1.0 wt. NiO-InTaO 4 , and (c) 1.0 wt. NiO-InTaO 4 R50-O200. P.-W.Pan, Y.-W.Chen / Catalysis Communications 8 (2007) 1546-1549 This research was supported by Industrial Technology Research Institute, Taiwan, Republic of China.
